P. 22800, Ensenada, México Here, it reports the influence of ultrasonic assistance during the impregnation process using traditional precursor salts of cobalt nitrate, molybdenum heptamolybdate, and citric acid as a chelating agent. The variation in metal loading (CoO + MoO3) from 16.1 wt% (12.7 wt% MoO3, 3.4 wt% CoO) to 46.8 wt% (35.7 wt% MoO3, 10.1 wt% CoO) was evaluated in the HDS of DBT. Ultrasonically-assisted impregnation demonstrated improved metal dispersion, improved the Co-Mo interactions and complete sulfidation of cobalt species, and enhanced the formation of well-dispersed CoMoS phase, unlike traditional impregnation catalysts that even exhibited non-sulfided Co species. Catalysts prepared using ultrasonic assistance exhibited a higher initial reaction rate for the HDS of DBT than their traditionally impregnated counterparts. Although the direct desulfurization pathway was the primary reaction route, the ultrasonic-assisted catalysts exhibited higher selectivity toward the hydrogenation pathway (higher HYD/DDS ratios), especially at higher metal loadings. The increased surface acidity, which correlated with rising metal content, enhanced the hydrogenation pathway during the HDS of DBT. Despite the superior catalytic performance of ultrasonic-assisted catalysts, the effectiveness of increasing metal content decreases at higher metal loadings, likely due to limitations in active site dispersion on the surface. Graphical Abstract Keywords Mesoporous materials Hydrodesulfurization catalysts Ultrasonically-assisted impregnation Innovative impregnation method Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Hydrodesulfurization (HDS) of petroleum fractions is essential in the refining industry [1]. Its importance has increased due to the increasing quantities of heavier feeds and the severe regulations on the permissible levels of sulfur, nitrogen-containing compounds, and aromatics in distillate fractions [2,3] . Strict environmental regulations on sulfur content in diesel fuel are driving refiners to develop novel catalysts for producing ultra-low sulfur diesel [4]. According to United States Environmental Protection Agency (USEPA) regulations, the sulfur limit was set to 30 ppm in 2017 and further reduced to 10 ppm in 2020 [5]. The typical HDS catalysts are molybdenum-based, promoted by Co and Ni, and usually supported on γ-Al2O3 [6]. Unfortunately, achieving the required sulfur limits in heavy petroleum fractions with traditional catalysts is complicated, especially for complex fractions like Maya-México oil, which is highly refractory and has sulfur levels up to 2800 ppm [7]. The demand to produce clean fuels and the difficulty of processing poor-quality petroleum feedstocks have increased interest in synthesizing novel and effective catalysts for deep HDS of diesel and gas oil. The unsupported NEBULA® catalysts, developed jointly by Akzo Nobel, Nippon Ketjen, and Exxon Mobil and commercialized in 2001, have proven to be much more effective for deep hydrotreating HDS reactions than traditional hydroprocessing catalysts [8]. However, these catalysts are more expensive than traditional supported ones, highlighting the need to design novel, cost-effective alternatives for effective HDS catalysts. Increasing the active phase load is an easy and effective way to enhance the catalytic activity of these catalysts. In industrial Co(Ni)Mo-based catalysts, the molybdenum content, expressed as MoO3, typically ranges from 10.9 % to 16.6 %wt., with an atomic ratio of Co(Ni)/(Mo+Co(Ni)) maintained around 0.35-0.50 [9]. Several reports have focused on investigative the impact of metal loading on catalytic activity in hydroprocessing reactions. Studies have shown that catalysts supported on γ-Al2O3 are most effective when the MoO3 content is around 13 %wt. (3.5–4.0 Mo atoms/nm2) [9,10]. Higher Mo contents lead to decreased dispersion of MoS2 phase, resulting in reduced catalytic activity. Additionally, excessive Mo content can cause pore blockage and increase the susceptibility of the active phase to sintering [10–12]. The load and distribution of metals on the surface γ-Al2O3 support primarily depend on the nature of the metal precursors; most molybdenum and cobalt salts have limited solubility [9]. Additionally, the pH of the impregnation solution must be significantly lowered due to the anionic nature of these salts to enhance the adsorption of metal species onto the aluminum oxide surface. However, this can sometimes partially dissolve the γ-Al2O3 surface, leading to various issues such as partial pore blockage and increased formation of inactive phases of Co(Ni) aluminates. Efforts to increase metal content have led to the use of alternative molybdenum salts to conventional ones. Using Keggin-type heteropolycompounds as precursors for CoMo catalysts results in catalysts with higher activity compared to those prepared with traditional salts like ammonium heptamolybdate [12,13]. M. Nikulshina et al. [9] synthesized alumina-based catalysts using simple heteropolycomposites of Co2Mo10, varying the total metal loading Co + Mo) from 6.5 % to 32 % by weight. The authors reported that the activity for HDS of dibenzothiophene (DBT) and hydrogenation (HYD) of naphthalene increased with higher metal loading, reaching peak activity at around 22 % by weight. However, beyond this metal content, the activity significantly declined. They also noted that, at higher metal contents, the degree of cobalt promotion decreased. The decrease in activity at higher metal contents may be attributed to the low surface area typically associated with γ-Al2O3. The synthesis of Mo-based supported catalysts with a higher concentration of active metals on the exterior surface and high dispersion remains a significant challenge in the catalyst industry. Several reports have highlighted the important role of support in enhancing the performance of supported catalysts during hydrotreating reactions. Utilizing novel structured materials to support hydrotreating catalysts could address this issue. Mesoporous silicate materials with ordered pore structures, such as HMS, MCM-41, and SBA-15, offer larger pore diameters and higher surface areas than Al2O3, making them attractive for developing high-performance hydrodesulfurization catalysts [14]. Ti-HMS, prepared using a neutral template pathway, offers advantages over Ti-MCM-41 and Ti-SBA-15 supports for preparing sulfide CoMo catalysts for dibenzothiophene hydrodesulfurization [7]. Using mesoporous materials like Ti-HMS, which offer a high surface area and large average pore diameter, could enable the development of a new generation of highly effective, high-metal-loading catalysts for the hydrodesulfurization of heavy fractions [7]. However, it is important to consider that incipient wetness and excess solution wet impregnation are the most common methods for synthesizing HDS catalysts. In this method, the maximum metal loading is constrained by surface oversaturation, which can lead to the formation of more complex species. These species may result in the formation of three-dimensional surface structures and, in some cases, crystalline phases. The distribution profile of the impregnated compound depends on the mass transfer conditions within the pores during impregnation and drying. Temperature, the primary operating variable, affects the precursors viscosity, which in turn influences the solutions diffusivity and the wetting time [15]. Traditional methods often fail to achieve high dispersion at high metal loading, limiting catalytic performance. Unconventional impregnation methods must be employed to obtain highly dispersed and effective catalysts with high metal loads. Advanced techniques, such as ultrasonically-assisted impregnation, can significantly enhance the development of next-generation catalysts [16,17]. Ultrasound can be defined as a propagation wave in the liquid that is based on alternating cycles of compression and rarefaction that drive the different stages of cavitation, generating microbubbles or cavities that collapse suddenly, resulting in significantly high and localized energy dissipation [15]. This sudden collapse increases the temperature in a highly localized manner and reduces mass transfer issues. Ultrasound can also enhance the interaction of precursor species with the surface, improving their dispersion. The ultrasonication method holds significant potential in catalyst manufacturing due to the high energy dissipation and localized heating it generates. It enhances the interaction of precursor species with the support surface, leading to better dispersion and increased loading of metal precursors on the support material [18]. Stucchi et al. [19] synthesized Ag nanoparticles from AgNO3 on micrometric TiO2 using H2O as a solvent and ultrasound irradiation at 30 W cm −2. This method resulted in a significantly higher surface amount of Ag on the TiO2 compared to catalysts prepared using traditional impregnation techniques. M. Stucchi et al. [20] synthesized copper nanoparticle-decorated TiO2 via ultrasonic assistance, varying the copper loads for the gas-phase photodegradation of acetone and acetaldehyde. The authors demonstrated that ultrasonic assistance modifies the TiO2 structure, even when it is commercial, enhancing its activation by visible light. The copper loading significantly influences the formation of different morphologies, significantly and positively affecting its photocatalytic activity. Abdollahifar et al. [21] synthesized a bimetallic Ni-Co/Al2O3 -MgO nanocatalyst using ultrasonic assistance for methane reforming. The sonochemically synthesized sample exhibited better textural properties and higher activity compared to the traditionally impregnated one. The authors observed a higher dispersion of particles in the sonochemically synthesized samples. Additionally, the sono-synthesized catalyst demonstrated significantly greater activity, selectivity, and stability compared to catalysts prepared via the traditional impregnation method. M.N. Goda et al. [22] reported the catalytic performance of CuxCo3 - xO4 catalysts for CO oxidation at relatively low temperatures, synthesized using a co-precipitation method assisted by ultrasonic radiation. The ultrasonic radiation increased particle dispersion and introduced Co2+ with Cu2+ in the CuxCo3 -xO4 catalysts, significantly enhancing their activity. Using ultrasonic assistance, P. Louyot et al. [23] synthesized bimetallic Co/Al2O3 and FeCo/Al2O3 catalysts for the Fischer-Tropsch reaction. The sonicated catalysts exhibited superior active phase dispersion compared to those synthesized without ultrasound assistance. The catalytic activity of the sonicated catalysts was significantly higher. N.A. Dhas et al. [24] reported a simple sonochemical synthesis of CoMoS/Al2O3, NiMoS/Al2O3, and CoNiMoS/Al2O3 catalysts for the hydrodesulfurization (HDS) of thiophene and dibenzothiophene. The catalytic performance of these sonochemically prepared catalysts was compared with that of traditional commercial catalysts. The synthesis involved ultrasonic irradiation of isobutene solutions containing Mo(CO)6 and Co2(CO)8 as metal sources. The sonochemically prepared CoMoS/Al2O3, NiMoS/Al2O3, and CoNiMoS/Al2O3 catalysts demonstrated significantly higher activity for HDS than comparable commercial catalysts. This enhanced performance is likely due to the higher dispersion of MoS2 on the support, leading to a greater concentration of catalytically active edge sites. Using ultrasonication treatment, M.V. Landau et al. [25] synthesized high-loading CoMo/MCM-41 catalysts. They precipitated the catalysts from Mo(CO)6 and Co(CO)3NO dissolved in decalin and tested their performance in the HDS of dibenzothiophene. The results were compared with those of a commercial CoMo/Al2O3 catalyst. The ultrasonic assistance induced chemical interactions between the metal carbonyl and surface silicates. The authors demonstrated that ultrasonication of the slurry results in the deposition-precipitation of the corresponding metal oxide, forming a close-packed monolayer on the support surface. Ultrasonically controlled deposition–precipitation produced a MoO3 loading of approximately 45 wt%. The high-loading CoMo/Al-MCM-41 catalyst prepared by this method was 1.7 times more active in the HDS of dibenzothiophene, based on the reaction rate normalized per catalyst weight than the commercial catalyst. Ultrasonic assistance will undoubtedly lead to synthesizing new generations of highly effective catalysts. However, specifically in HDS catalysts, metal carbonyls of Mo, Ni, and Co are generally used as precursors, making the process extremely expensive and complicated due to the need to prevent oxidation by atmospheric oxygen. The challenge is applying this new ultrasonic assistance method in synthesizing catalysts using traditional metal precursors. This study explores the ultrasound-assisted impregnation method using traditional precursor salts of Co and Mo metals, specifically cobalt nitrate, molybdenum heptamolybdate, and citric acid as a chelating agent. The effect of varying metal loadings from 16.1 wt% (12.7 wt% MoO3, 3.4 wt% CoO) to 46.8 wt% (35.7 wt% MoO3, 10.1 wt% CoO) was examined in the hydrodesulfurization (HDS) reaction of dibenzothiophene. 2 Experimental 2.1 Synthesis of the Ti-HMS materials The Ti-HMS material was prepared following a previously described procedure [7]. Our earlier studies have shown that a Si/Ti molar ratio of 40 is most effective for preparing CoMo-based catalysts for hydrodesulfurization reactions. Therefore, we synthesized the Ti-HMS material with this specific atomic ratio in this study. The reaction products were filtered, washed with distilled water, and dried at room temperature for 24 h. This was followed by drying at 100 °C for 12 h and then calcination at 500°C for 5 h in static air. 2.2 Catalysts synthesis 2.2.1 Traditional impregnation method Three catalysts were prepared using the impregnation method with a pore-filling method. The metal loadings were 12.8, 18.8, and 24.4 wt% as MoO3, with the appropriate amount of Co to maintain a Co/Co + Mo) atomic ratio of 0.48. An aqueous solution of ammonium heptamolybdate (Aldrich 99 %), cobalt nitrate (Aldrich 98 %), and citric acid (Aldrich 98 %) was prepared, maintaining a Mo/citric acid atomic ratio of 2. The samples were then dried at room temperature for 18 h, then at 120 °C for 12 h, and finally calcined at 500 °C for 5 h. 2.2.2 Ultrasonically-assisted impregnation method A series of catalysts were prepared using the ultrasound-assisted impregnation method, varying the total metal oxide content of CoO and MoO3 from 16.4 % to 45 %wt. The catalysts featured MoO3 loadings of 12.8 %, 18.8 %, 24.4 %, 29.8 %, and 34.9 %wt., with the appropriate amount of Co to maintain a Co/Co + Mo) atomic ratio of 0.48. The ultrasound-assisted impregnation was performed using the wet impregnation method with a light excess solution, maintaining a 1.8 mL/g support ratio. Two grams of support were placed in 3.6 mL of an aqueous solution containing ammonium heptamolybdate, cobalt nitrate, and citric acid, maintaining a Mo/citric acid molar ratio 2. Sonication was performed using a high-intensity Ti-horn sonicator (20 kHz, 100 W/cm2) at room temperature under ambient air for up to 4 h. The sample was then allowed to rest for 6 h, followed by a second sonication for 2 h. The samples were then dried at room temperature for 24 h, followed by drying at 120 °C for 18 h, and finally calcined at 500 °C for 5 h. 2.3 Characterization methods The molybdenum, cobalt and titanium content were quantified using an ICP-AES Perkin Elmer Optima 3300DV instrument. Textural properties were evaluated using the N2 adsorption-desorption isotherms at −196 °C on a Micromeritics TRISTAR III system. Before the analysis, samples were pre-treated by outgassing at 200 °C for 10 h. X-ray diffraction measurements were performed using a PANalytical Aeris diffractometer outfitted with a Pixel 1D detector and a Cu Kα radiation source (λ = 1.5405 Å), with a step size of 0.021 °/min, in the 2θ range of 10–60°. The UV–vis diffuse reflectance spectroscopy (DRS UV–vis) measurements were carried out with an Agilent Cary-5000 UV-Vis spectrophotometer equipped with a Praying Mantis diffuse reflection reaction cell (Harrick Scientific). Temperature-programmed reduction (TPR) analyses were conducted using a Quantachrome ChemBET Pulsar equipment. About 30 mg of the sample was first degassed at 150 °C under a N2 flow for 1 h. After cooling to room temperature, the TPR analysis was performed by heating the sample in a U-tube reactor to 1000 °C at 10 °C/min in a 10 % H2/Ar mixture at 25 mL/min. Micro-Raman spectroscopy was carried out at room temperature in a micro-Raman system (Labram model of Dilor) equipped with a 20 mW He-Ne laser emitting at 532 nm. X-ray photoelectron spectra (XPS) were acquired using a SPECS® spectrometer with a PHOIBOS® 150 WAL hemispherical energy analyzer with sub-degree angular resolution (< 0.5 °), equipped with both XR 50 Al-X-ray and μ-FOCUS 500 X-ray monochromator sources for Al excitation lines. Charge-related effects were adjusted by setting the C 1 s peak binding energies of adventitious carbon to 284.5 eV. FTIR spectroscopy of adsorbed pyridine on sulfide samples was carried out in an Agilent 660 spectroscopy equipped with an ISRI transmission heated cell and an in situ high-low pressure infrared reactor with CaF2 windows. The self-supporting wafers of the catalysts, with a thickness of 60 mg cm −2, were prepared by pressing the powdered samples at a pressure of 8 tons for 20 min. Before the experiments, the self-supporting wafers were sulfided with a mixture of H2/H2S (10 vol% H2S) at a 60 mL/min flow rate at 400 °C for 2 h. The sample was then cooled to 100°C under a nitrogen flow, followed by degassing under vacuum (10 −5 mbar) for 1 h. Subsequently, the sample was exposed to 5 mbar pyridine (98 %, Sigma Aldrich) for 30 min. The concentration of the Brønsted and Lewis acid sites was determined from the integral areas of the absorption bands at 1543 and 1450 cm −1, respectively, using the molar absorption coefficients reported by C.A. Emeis [26] for the Brønsted (1.67 cm·μmol −1) and Lewis (2.22 cm·μmol −1) acid-sites. NO adsorption was carried out following a similar sulfidation procedure as before, except that the sample was collected at room temperature after sulfidation. The samples were then degassed under vacuum (10 −5 mbar) for 1 h and subsequently exposed to 20 mbar NO for 5 min. The spectrum was recorded at a resolution of 4 cm −1. Afterward, the sample was degassed for 2 h to ensure complete desorption of NO molecules, and the catalyst spectrum was recorded again. The IR spectrum of the adsorbed NO was obtained by subtracting the spectrum of the corresponding degassed catalyst. TEM images of the samples were obtained using a JEOL JEM-2100 F (STEM) microscope with energy-dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (EDX), operating at 200 kV and 54 μA. 2.4 Catalytic activity measurements The catalytic activity for the HDS of DBT was measured in a batch Parr reactor with 0.2 g of catalyst and 0.3 g of DBT dissolved in 100 mL of n-hexadecane. The reactor was purged with nitrogen to remove oxygen traces. First, sulfurization of the catalysts was performed in a fixed bed reactor with a gas mixture of 15 %H2S/85 %H2 (Infra) at a flow of 60 mL min−1, raising the temperature at a rate of 10 °C to 400 °C min−1 during 2 h. Then, the samples were cooled down to room temperature under a nitrogen flow and were placed into of the batch reactor. The reaction was conducted for 6 hours at 320 °C under a hydrogen pressure of 54 atm of hydrogen. To exclude external diffusion limitations, the reaction mixture was stirred intensively (checked by varying the amount of catalyst and stirring power at 1000, 800, and 700 rpm). All catalysts were ground to a fine powder to minimize internal diffusion limitations. The reactor took 35 minutes to reach the reaction temperature. Reaction products were analyzed by GC using a Perkin-Elmer XL with a 30 m Altech econo capillary column. The mass balance in all experiments was within 99.0-99.98 %. The degree of DBT conversion was used to measure catalytic activity. For comparison, a commercial KF-752 catalyst (Akzo Nobel) containing 4.9 wt% CoO and 17.5 wt% MoO3, and an atomic ratio of Co/Co + Mo) of 0.48, was used as a reference. 3 Results 3.1 Characterization of oxidized catalysts Table 1 presents the labeling, textural properties, and chemical composition of the catalysts synthesized by conventional and ultrasonically-assisted impregnation methods. The theoretical metal loading and sample descriptions are indicated in the first column. The experimental composition, determined by ICP-AES, is close to the theoretical MoO3 loaded values, indicating that the desired amount of metal was successfully incorporated. It is important to note that, regardless of the metal loading and the preparation method used, all catalysts exhibited a consistent atomic ratio of Co/Co + Mo) between 0.47 and 0.49. Therefore, the catalysts are referred to based on their MoO3 loading, as the Co loading is proportional to maintaining the specified atomic ratio. The N2 adsorption isotherms of the bare Ti-HMS, as well as the catalysts prepared by the impregnation method and the ultrasonically-assisted impregnation method, exhibit a type IV isotherm, according to the IUPAC classification (data not shown). The pore structure parameters, such as the specific area (SBET), cumulative pore volume (Vp), and average pore diameter (dp) of the catalysts prepared by the impregnation method and the ultrasonically-assisted impregnation method are listed in Table 1. The specific surface area of the Ti-HMS support was 924 m2/g, with Vp and dp values of 1.48 cm3/g and 7.3 nm, respectively. The introduction of metals led to a significant reduction in the textural parameters, with the most pronounced decrease observed in the catalysts prepared using the conventional impregnation method (Imp-series). The Imp-12 catalyst, with 12.8 % MoO3, exhibits the highest surface area and larger pore size compared to the other catalysts prepared by this impregnation method. As the metal content increases, the surface area decreases, with the most significant reduction observed in the Imp-24 catalyst (Table 1), reflecting a 34 % decrease in surface area compared to Imp-12. A similar trend was observed for the Vp and dp values. The ultrasonically-assisted impregnation method (US-series) shows higher surface areas and pore sizes than the conventional method for similar metal loadings. For example, US-12 catalysts, with 12.8 % MoO3, have a significantly higher surface area and larger pore size than Imp-12 (Table 1). This trend continues across the series, with ultrasonically-assisted catalysts retaining higher surface areas and pore volumes at higher metal loadings, such as US-24 with 24.2 % MoO3 compared to Imp-24 (similar metal loaded). At higher loadings, such as US-30 catalysts, the surface area decreases as expected but remains higher than the conventionally prepared samples. These observations similarly apply to the Vp and dp values (Table 1). An ultrasonically-assisted catalyst was even prepared with a metal loading of up to 35.7 % MoO3 (US-36), which exhibited an SBET value notably higher than the Imp-24 catalyst, which contains only 24.1 % MoO3. The textural properties data clearly show that the ultrasonically-assisted method is more effective at maintaining higher surface areas and larger pore diameters, even with increasing metal content. This suggests that ultrasound improves the dispersion of the phases, minimizing pore blockage and preserving textural properties. Fig. 1 presents the XRD patterns of the catalysts prepared by the traditional (a) and the ultrasonically-assisted impregnation method (b), recorded within the 5-80 ° 2θ range. Regardless of the preparation method, a broad diffraction peak between 20° and 30° in 2θ is observed, corresponding to the amorphous phase of the supports [27]. The diffraction patterns of the catalysts prepared by impregnation exhibited higher intensity peaks compared to those synthesized via ultrasonically-assisted method (Fig. 1). For the catalyst with the lowest metal loading (Imp-12), a low-intensity peak at around 23.3° in 2θ, corresponding to the MoO3 phase in the (110) plane, was observed (Fig. 1a). As the Mo and Co loadings increased, additional diffraction peaks appeared. The Imp-18 catalyst showed four low-intensity peaks at 23.4°, 25.7°, 27.3°, and 33.6°, corresponding to the (110), (040), (021), and (111) planes of MoO3, respectively. At even higher metal loadings, the Imp-24 catalyst displayed two more peaks at 39.5° and 46.4°, associated with the MoO3 phase in the (060) and (210) planes. Notably, the diffraction peaks for Imp-24 were significantly more intense compared to the other catalysts prepared by the same method (Fig. 1a). In contrast, the catalysts prepared with ultrasonic assistance (Fig. 1 b) showed only a low-intensity peak at 27.3°, corresponding to the (021) plane of MoO3, and this peak was not observed until the US-24 catalyst. Despite US-24 having a similar metal loading to Imp-24, the latter exhibited much higher intensity MoO3 diffraction peaks (Fig. 1). For the catalysts with higher Mo and Co loadings, such as US-30 and US-36, the peak at 27.3° began to appear but remained much lower in intensity compared to the impregnated samples. Additionally, a slight diffraction peak at 25.7°, corresponding to the (040) plane of MoO3, was detected in US-36, although with very low intensity. The results suggest that ultrasonically-assisted impregnation enhances the dispersion of supported components on the surface, effectively preventing excessive crystal growth and promoting the distribution of low-crystallinity particles, offering significant advantages in preparing high metal loading catalysts compared to traditional impregnation techniques. The UV-Vis DRS technique was employed to investigate the influence of the preparation method and metal loading on the chemical coordination of the supported Co and Mo species. Fig. 2 shows the DRS UV-Vis spectra of calcined catalysts prepared by the traditional (a) and the ultrasonically-assisted impregnation method (b). The spectra of the catalysts prepared by the impregnation method exhibit bands around 358, 523, 582, and 641 nm (Fig. 2a). The absorption band at 358 nm is attributed to the ligand-to-metal charge transfer (LMCT) of O2− → Mo6⁺ species in octahedral coordination [28]. The intensity of this band increases slightly with higher Co and Mo loadings, indicating that the amount of octahedral Mo species exposed on the surface increases as the metal loading rises (Fig. 2a). The absorption band observed at 523 nm is attributed to Laporte-forbidden but spin-allowed d-d transitions of Co2⁺ species, which are associated with octahedral coordination in CoMo catalysts supported on SiO2-based supports [29]. The band at 582 nm corresponds to d-d electronic transitions (4T2g to 4A2g and 4T2g to 4T1g) in high-spin octahedral Co2⁺ species interacting with molybdenum. These octahedral ions are readily sulfided, forming active species for catalytic hydrodesulfurization reactions [30]. The lower intensity absorption band around 641 nm is likely due to tetrahedral Co2⁺ species, possibly within the Co2SiO4 phase or strongly interacting with the support surface [30]. The intensity of these absorption bands also increased with higher metal loading, with the most significant increase observed in the bands at 523 and 641 nm. This is evident when comparing the intensity of these two bands between the Imp-12 and Imp-24 catalysts (Fig. 2a). The DRS UV–vis spectra of the catalysts prepared using the ultrasonic-assisted method differ significantly from those of the catalysts prepared by the conventional method (Fig. 2). The spectra of these catalysts displayed bands at 275, 362, 446, 580, and 625 nm (Fig. 2b). As previously mentioned, the band at 362 nm is attributed to the ligand-to-metal charge transfer LMCT of O2− → Mo6⁺ species in octahedral coordination [28]. Meanwhile, the absorption band at 275 nm is associated with isolated MoO4 2− species in tetrahedral coordination [30]. The intensity of the absorption band related to tetrahedral MoO4 2− species at 275 nm increased slightly with rising metal loading until the US-30 catalyst. At higher metal content (US-36 catalyst), this band showed a more significant increase in intensity. This suggests a gradual increase in the amount of tetrahedral Mo species with increasing metal loading, which becomes more noticeable between catalysts US-30 and US-36. In contrast, the absorption band associated with Mo species in octahedral coordination at 362 nm showed a significant and gradual increase with increasing metal loading (Fig. 2b). This indicates that ultrasonic assistance during catalyst synthesis promoted the formation of these octahedral species, which, as mentioned earlier, are less reducible during the sulfidation process. The absorption band at 435 nm is attributed to the O2− → Co2⁺ charge transfer transition in octahedral coordination, while the band at 582 nm corresponds to octahedral Co2⁺ species interacting with molybdenum ions [30–33]. Notably, the absorption band at 641 nm, which is associated with Co species in tetrahedral coordination within the Co2SiO4 phase or strongly interacting with the support surface, was absent in the catalysts prepared using ultrasonic assistance. This suggests that this technique may inhibit the formation of this phase, which is typically challenging to reduce under the sulfidation conditions employed in this study. Although tetrahedrally coordinated molybdenum species (band at 275 nm) were present in the ultrasonically-assisted catalysts (Fig. 2b), the formation of octahedral species (band at 362 nm) was significantly more pronounced. This indicates that ultrasonically-assisted synthesis promotes the formation of octahedral species. When comparing the spectra of catalysts prepared by both methods, it is evident that the formation of octahedral species is considerably higher in the ultrasonically-assisted catalysts. Furthermore, ultrasound-assisted synthesis significantly enhances the formation of octahedral Co species while inhibiting the formation of tetrahedral coordination Co species, compared to catalysts prepared by conventional methods (Fig. 2a and b). It is also noteworthy that ultrasonic assistance inhibited the formation of the inactive Co2SiO4 phase. TPR-H2 analysis was conducted to evaluate the influence of the preparation method and metal loading on the reduction behavior of the metals and their interaction with the support. Fig. 3 shows the TPR-H2 profiles of the reference monometallic catalysts, Co(4 wt%)/Ti-HMS (Imp_Co-4) and Mo(12 wt%)/Ti-HMS (Imp_Mo-12), synthesized by the impregnation method (a), along with catalysts prepared using the traditional (b) and ultrasonically-assisted impregnation method (c). The Co monometallic catalyst (Imp_Co-4) exhibits two reduction peaks centered at 320 and 417 °C (Fig. 3a), corresponding to the reduction of Co3⁺ to Co2⁺ and Co2⁺ to Co0, respectively [34,35]. The monometallic Mo catalyst (Imp_Mo-12) also shows two reduction peaks, centered at 583 and 733 °C (Fig. 3a), which are associated with the reduction of Mo6⁺ to Mo4⁺ and Mo4⁺ to Mo0, respectively [36,37]. The reduction peaks of the Imp_Mo-12 catalyst appear at significantly higher temperatures compared to those of the Imp_Co-4 catalyst, allowing for the identification of Co species that do not interact with Mo species. The TPR-H2 profiles for CoMo catalysts synthesized by the traditional impregnation method exhibit two main reduction peaks between 515 and 550 °C and the second at higher temperatures, between 727 and 736 °C (Fig. 3b). Notably, the characteristic reduction peaks for cobalt oxide species are absent, suggesting that most Co species interact with Mo ions. This is likely because most of the cobalt oxide was reduced at temperatures below 500 °C. It has been reported that the reduction of Mo species interacting with Co ions (Co–Mo species) occurs at lower temperatures compared to the reduction of bare Mo species. Additionally, the presence of Co oxide is known to inhibit the reduction of Co species by polarizing the Co–O bonds, making them more ionic and, consequently, more difficult to reduce [38]. Therefore, it can be inferred that the main reduction peak observed in the bimetallic catalysts corresponds to the reduction of Mo species interacting with cobalt ions. As expected, hydrogen consumption increases with higher metal loading. It is also observed that the main reduction peak shifts to higher temperatures as the metal content increases, from 515 °C for the Imp-12 catalyst to 550 °C for the Imp-24 catalyst (Fig. 3b). This shift could indicate a decrease in the interactions between Co and Mo species, possibly due to increased crystal size or stronger interactions of the formed species with the support. The width and intensity of the reduction peak at 727–736 °C also increase with higher metal loading. This behavior could be attributed to the reduction of Mo4⁺species to Mo0 that do not interact with cobalt ions (Fig. 3b). Additionally, overlapping reductions may contribute to this peak, including the reduction of tetrahedral cobalt species strongly interacting with the support (Co2SiO4 phase), as suggested by UV-Vis DRS, which occurs at similar temperatures in this reduction region. Similarly, the characteristic reduction peaks for cobalt oxide species were absent in the reduction profiles of the ultrasonically-assisted catalysts (Fig. 3c), suggesting that most Co species are likely interacting with Mo ions. The TPR-H2 profiles for CoMo catalysts prepared using the ultrasonically-assisted method show two distinct reduction peaks: the first appearing between 500 and 538 °C, and the second at higher temperatures, ranging from 727 to 736 °C (Fig. 3b). As previously mentioned, the main reduction peak is attributed to the reduction of Mo species that are interacting with cobalt ions. The reduction temperature of this peak increased with higher metal loading but was observed at lower temperatures compared to catalysts synthesized by traditional impregnation (Fig. 3b and c). For instance, the reduction peak for the US-24 catalyst appears at 518°C, while the Imp-24 catalyst with the same metal loading occurs at 550°C. The peak width is slightly narrower for the ultrasonically-assisted catalysts, and the hydrogen consumption is significantly higher. This suggests the formation of more uniform species in terms of size (as indicated by the narrower peak) and higher dispersion (evidenced by the increase in the TCD signal). The reduction signal in the 727 – 736 °C range began to appear faintly in sample US-18 and became more pronounced in sample US-24. Although the intensity of this signal increased with higher metal loading, it remained noticeably lower than in the catalysts synthesized using the impregnation method. For instance, a significant difference in the intensity of this signal can be seen when comparing US-24 to Imp-24, both with the same metal loading. This suggests a reduction in the amount of Co species strongly interacting with the support, indicating that most of the Mo is interacting with cobalt, as evidenced by the lower temperature reduction peak observed between 500 and 538 °C. The TPR-H2 profiles indicate that ultrasound-assisted synthesis results in lower reduction temperatures for Co-Mo species compared to the traditional impregnation method, potentially producing species with a higher degree of sulfidability, which is important for forming the main active phase. Additionally, the ultrasound-assisted method shows a significant reduction in the strong interaction of Co species with the support, along with an increase in Mo species that interact more effectively with cobalt. Since the catalysts studied contain d0 transition metal oxides (molybdenum oxides) and d5 (cobalt oxides) species, Raman spectroscopy was employed to identify the types of metal oxide species present in the calcined catalysts. Fig. 4 shows the Raman spectra of calcined catalysts prepared by the traditional (a) and ultrasonically-assisted impregnation method (b). Regardless of the preparation method, the spectra reveal several Raman bands in all catalysts exhibiting shift bands at 986, 952, 918, and 845 cm −1. The most intense band, around 952 cm −1, corresponds to the symmetric M=OT (terminal bonding) vibration associated with Mo7O24 6− species [39,40]. The bands at 986 cm −1 and 845 cm −1 are attributed to the symmetric and asymmetric vibrations of Mo-O-Mo bridges in polymolybdates formed on the support surface [40–42]. The Raman band at 918 cm −1 is likely due to the symmetric M=OT in the Mo8O26 4− species [43,44]. Notably, no Raman shift signals characteristic of cobalt oxides were observed, suggesting that most cobalt interacts with molybdenum species, as supported by the TPR results. As expected, increasing the metal content results in an intensified Raman band signal (Fig. 4). However, notable differences appear between catalysts prepared by traditional impregnation and those synthesized with ultrasound-assisted impregnation, suggesting variations in the oxide species present on the surface. The highest Raman band intensities are observed in the ultrasound-assisted catalysts, indicating that this method promotes a greater quantity of oxide species on the surface (Fig. 4b) compared to those in the traditionally impregnated samples (Fig. 4a). In ultrasound-assisted catalysts, higher metal loading promotes the formation of polymolybdates with both terminal Mo bonds (MoOT) and Mo-O-Mo bonds, with a notably greater proportion of MoOT species compared to bulk Mo-O-Mo (Fig. 4b). Conversely, catalysts prepared by traditional impregnation slightly prefer Mo-O-Mo bond formation over MoOT bonds (Fig. 4a). A higher proportion of molybdenum species with terminal bonds (MoOT) compared to those with Mo-O-Mo bonds indicates the irregular crystal morphology of the molybdenum oxide species, characterized by a greater number of edge atoms. In MoOT double-bond species, molybdenum atoms are less electronically saturated than those in Mo-O-Mo bonds, making them more susceptible to sulfidation. These species likely play a crucial role in the formation of active catalytic sites. To assess the irregularity of the crystalline phase of the supported molybdenum oxide species (edge and bulk molybdenum species), the intensity ratio of MoOT/Mo-O-Mo (bands at 952 cm −1 and 986 cm −1) was calculated. The Raman intensity ratio is lower in samples prepared by the traditional impregnation method, decreasing as metal content increases, following the order: Imp-12 (1.61) > Imp-18 (1.47) > Imp-24 (1.21). In contrast, in the ultrasonically-assisted samples, this intensity ratio increases with higher metal content, as follows: US-12 (2.23) < US-18 (2.31) < US-24 (2.61) < US-30 (2.70) < US-36 (2.80). These results confirm that ultrasonic-assisted impregnation more effectively controls the crystallinity of oxide species, resulting in a lower degree of MoO3 crystallization compared to the traditional impregnation method, as inferred from XRD results. The ultrasonic method promotes the formation of more dispersed and less aggregated Mo species, potentially enhancing catalytic performance. 3.2 Characterization of sulfided catalysts Infrared spectroscopy of chemisorbed NO was utilized to determine the chemical state and surface dispersion of cobalt and molybdenum on the sulfided catalysts. Fig. 5 shows the FTIR spectra of adsorbed NO on the freshly sulfided catalysts catalysts prepared by the traditional (a) and ultrasonically-assisted impregnation method (b). As expected, all catalysts, regardless of preparation method, exhibited an intense doublet at 1856 and 1772 cm⁻1 (Fig. 5a and b), corresponding to the symmetric and asymmetric stretching vibrations of NO adsorbed on sulfided Co2⁺ ions, respectively [45,46]. As expected, the intensity of these absorption bands increased with rising metal content. Notably, this increase in intensity relative to metal content was more pronounced on the ultrasonically-assisted sulfide catalysts, suggesting that these samples may have a higher concentration of sulfided cobalt ions exposed on the surface compared to those prepared by the traditional impregnation method. Further, the catalysts prepared by the traditional impregnation method showed an additional absorption band at higher frequencies at 1872 cm −1 (Fig. 5a). This band is characteristic of the lower-intensity component of a doublet, typically observed at 1872 and 1800 cm −1, which corresponds to the symmetric and asymmetric stretching vibrations of NO adsorbed on sulfided Co2⁺ ions [47,48]. The absorption band of this doublet, which should appear around 1800 cm −1, overlaps with the band observed at 1792 cm −1. However, the presence of the band at 1872 cm −1 clearly indicates the existence of oxygen-bound Co2⁺ species (oxidized species). This suggests that the supported cobalt species are not fully sulfided when the traditional impregnation method prepares the catalysts. This finding aligns with previous studies we conducted on cobalt-based catalysts promoted with Co or Ni via traditional impregnation [43,45–49], which indicated that this method tends to form promoter species (Co or Ni) with a strong interaction with the surface, thereby hindering their reducibility and sulfidation (as observed in DRS UV–vis and TPR results). The absence of this doublet, associated with oxidized cobalt species, in the sulfided catalysts prepared by the ultrasound-assisted method indicates that this method favors the formation of cobalt species with high reducibility and sulfidability. Thus, ultrasonic assistance appears to have a positive effect not only on enhancing the dispersion of the active phase but also on optimizing its sulfidability, which is essential for catalytic activity. Additionally, each catalyst displayed an absorption band at a lower frequency, around 1628 cm −1 (Fig. 5a and b). This band is reported as the main peak of a doublet typically found at approximately 1630 and 1764 cm −1, which is associated with the symmetric and asymmetric stretching vibrations of NO adsorbed on sulfided Moδ⁺ ions [49]. Notably, the 1764 cm −1 band in this doublet overlaps with the primary band of NO species adsorbed on sulfided cobalt species (absorption band at 1792 cm −1). The intensity of the absorption band at 1628 cm −1 also increased with higher metal content and was slightly greater in the ultrasonically-assisted samples. The increased intensity of the band at 1628 cm −1 indicates enhanced dispersion of molybdenum sulfide species and is associated with greater so-called brim sites in the MoS2 phase. This suggests a higher concentration of these species exposed on the surface of catalysts prepared using this method. The FT-IR spectra indicates that the ultrasound-assisted impregnation method improves the dispersion of Mo and Co species on the Ti-HMS surface. The absence of the 1872 cm −1 band (attributed to oxidized Co2+ ions) in ultrasound-assisted catalysts suggests that this method promotes more complete sulfidation of cobalt species, reducing the formation of inactive Co oxide ions. Additionally, the increased intensity of the bands at 1792 and 1856 cm −1 (attributed to sulfided Co2+ ions) with higher metal loading, especially in ultrasound-assisted samples, indicates a higher concentration of dispersed active sites. These findings suggest that the ultrasound-assisted impregnation method enhances the dispersion and the sulfidation of Co ions, potentially contributing to forming CoMoS active sites, which are essential for catalytic processes like HDS. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy offered insights into surface Co and Mo species exposure and the types of species formed upon sulfidation. The Mo 3d and Co 2p core-level spectra for the freshly sulfided catalysts, prepared by traditional impregnation and ultrasonic-assisted impregnation methods, are displayed in Figs. 6 and 7, respectively. Table 2 shows the binding energy (B.E.) values of core electrons for Mo 3d5/2, Co 2p3/2, and S 2p, along with surface atomic ratios (Co/Si, Mo/Si, and S/(Co+Mo)) for freshly sulfided CoMo/Ti-HMS catalysts prepared by traditional and ultrasonic-assisted impregnation. All catalysts display the S 2p peak at 162.2 ± 0.1 eV, characteristic of S2⁻ ions in the MoS2 structure [45,46]. The absence of a secondary B.E. component around 168 eV, where sulfate species typically appear [45–47], indicates that the sulfidation procedure and sample transfer within the spectrometer chamber effectively prevented air exposure. The Mo 3d spectra of freshly sulfided catalysts prepared by the traditional impregnation method show the most intense Mo 3d5/2 peak at a B.E. of 228.6 eV (Fig. 6a). This value is slightly higher than the typical 228 eV observed for stoichiometric MoS2 [45,47,48], suggesting an interaction between the molybdenum species and the support surface. The absence of peaks corresponding to molybdenum oxy-sulfide species (such as MoO2S2 2−) confirms complete sulfidation of the molybdenum oxide species [49]. Therefore, the B.E. at 228.6 eV can be attributed to the MoS2 phase. A slight increase in counts per second was observed with increasing metal content, indicating a higher concentration of molybdenum species as the metal loading rises (Fig. 6a). Only the MoS2 phase is observed on these catalysts, indicating that all molybdenum species were fully sulfided. In contrast, cobalt species in catalysts prepared by traditional impregnation are only partially sulfide (Fig. 7a). The curve fitting of the Co 2p spectra reveals two states with B.E. values of Co 2p3/2 at 778.1 and 780.7 eV. The B.E. at 778.1 eV is characteristic of the CoS2 phase [50], while the higher B.E. value at 780.7 eV corresponds to non-sulfidized Co2⁺ ions [49,50], consistent with observations from FTIR of adsorbed NO (Fig. 5a). The lower metal-loaded catalyst synthesized by this method (Imp-12) exhibited approximately 61 % sulfidation of the cobalt species on the surface (Table 2). Additionally, the degree of sulfidation gradually increased with rising metal content, reaching up to 70 % in the Imp-24 sample (Table 2). This suggests that as the metal content increases, the interaction of cobalt species with the surface decreases, making sulfidation easier. Alternatively, it could indicate that cobalt species strongly interact with the surface and are covered by additional Co and Mo species. The counts per second increased with higher metal loading, suggesting a greater amount of exposed cobalt species as metal content rises. The B.E. values for the Mo 3d5/2 peak in the ultrasonically-assisted catalysts appeared at 228.1 eV, characteristic of the MoS2 phase [50]. Notably, this value shifted toward lower binding energies compared to catalysts synthesized via the traditional impregnation method (228.6 eV). The decrease in binding energy suggests that the Mo species are gaining electrons or enriching their electronic environment, indicating an increase in their metallicity or metallic character. Unlike the catalysts prepared by traditional impregnation, curve fitting of the Co 2p spectra for the ultrasonically-assisted catalysts reveals a single Co 2p3/2 peak at 778.9 eV. This energy is characteristic of sulfided cobalt species [49,50], although it is 0.8 eV higher than the binding energy observed in catalysts synthesized by traditional impregnation (Table 2). This increase in binding energy suggests a reduction in electron density around the cobalt species. This shift allows us to infer that the electronic enrichment observed in the sulfided molybdenum species could be due to partial electron transfer from cobalt to molybdenum. This electron transfer may explain the changes in binding energies of both cobalt and molybdenum species in the ultrasonically-assisted catalysts. Consequently, a stronger interaction between Co and Mo species in these catalysts is suggested, indicating that ultrasonic assistance favors the formation of the CoMoS phase, recognized as the primary active site model in hydroprocessing catalysts. The Mo/Si and Co/Si surface ratios shown in Table 2 allow us to assess the influence of the synthesis method on the amount of Mo and Co species exposed on the catalyst surface. As expected, the Co/Si and Mo/Si surface atomic ratios increased with rising metal content for both preparation methods. Overall, the Co/Si and Mo/Si values are lower in catalysts synthesized by the traditional impregnation method compared to those prepared with ultrasonic assistance. This suggests that catalysts synthesized with ultrasonic assistance have a higher surface exposure of Co and Mo species, indicating that ultrasonic assistance enhances the dispersion of active species (as observed in DRS UV–vis, TPR and Raman results). XPS results reveal significant differences between catalyst synthesis methods in terms of the dispersion, cobalt sulfidation, and electronic interactions between species. The ultrasound-assisted impregnation method enhances the sulfidation of cobalt species and significantly increases the surface exposure of the Co and Mo species. Additionally, changes observed in the electronic environment of Mo and Co species in ultrasonically-assisted catalysts suggest a stronger Co-Mo interaction compared to those synthesized by traditional impregnation. This enhanced interaction in ultrasonically-assisted catalysts indicates a favorable environment for the formation of the CoMoS phase (as observed in FTIR of adsorbed NO results), which is critical for catalytic performance in hydroprocessing reactions. FTIR spectroscopy of adsorbed pyridine was conducted to determine the type and concentration of acid sites on the freshly sulfided catalysts. The FTIR spectra of adsorbed pyridine on catalysts prepared by traditional and ultrasonic-assisted impregnation method are shown in Fig. 8a and b, respectively. All catalysts present similar spectra, featuring four adsorption bands at 1445, 1487, 1547, and 1607 cm −1. The band at 1547 cm −1 is indicative of pyridine chemisorbed on Brønsted acid sites, while the band at 1445 cm − ¹ corresponds to pyridine on Lewis acid sites [7,27,49]. The band at 1487 cm − ¹ represents symmetrical vibrations from both Lewis and Brønsted acid sites [7,27,49], and the band at 1607 cm − ¹ is associated with hydrogen bonded, chemisorbed pyridine [7,27,49]. Table 3 presents the quantities of Lewis and Brønsted acid sites obtained through quantitative analysis of the FT-IR spectra, along with the total acidity and the Brønsted/Lewis acid site ratio. The Brønsted and Lewis acid site concentrations were determined from the integrated areas of the bands at approximately 1545 and 1450 cm − ¹ , respectively, using the extinction coefficients reported by C.A. Emeis [26]. As shown in Fig. 8a and b, regardless of the preparation method, the bands associated with Brønsted acid sites (1547 cm−1) and Lewis acid sites (1445 cm−1) gradually increase with rising metal loading. Except for the Imp-12 catalyst, the spectra reveal relatively higher Brønsted acidity (1547 cm−1 band) in catalysts synthesized by the traditional impregnation method (Fig. 8a and b). Similarly, Lewis acidity is consistently higher in catalysts prepared by this method. We can compare the highest metal-loaded catalyst from each method to evaluate the impact of preparation methods on acid sites. The Imp-24 catalyst, with 24.1 wt% MoO3, has a Brønsted acid site concentration of 0.30 μmol gcat⁻1 and a Lewis site concentration of 2.88 μmol gcat −1. In contrast, the US-36 catalyst (35.7 wt% MoO3) has a Brønsted site concentration of 0.29 μmol gcat −1 and a Lewis site concentration of 2.54 μmol gcat −1. Despite the US-36 catalyst containing up to 1.5 times more metal than Imp-24, it shows a lower concentration of Brønsted and Lewis acid sites. Consequently, total acidity (Brønsted plus Lewis) is higher in catalysts synthesized by traditional impregnation. This suggests that Co and Mo species may interact more strongly with -OH groups on the surface in ultrasonically assisted catalysts, reducing surface acidity. This interaction likely promotes better dispersion, as the XPS characterizations indicate. The influence of the preparation method on Lewis and Brønsted acid sites can be further assessed by the Brønsted/Lewis (B/L) acid site ratio. This ratio decreases gradually with increasing metal content. However, the B/L ratio is consistently higher in ultrasonically-assisted catalysts compared to those synthesized by the traditional method. This indicates that ultrasonically-assisted catalysts exhibit a higher proportion of Brønsted sites relative to Lewis sites on their surface. The higher B/L ratio in ultrasonically-assisted catalysts may enhance catalytic activity in hydrodesulfurization (HDS), as Brønsted acid sites facilitate hydrogen transfer reactions, which are essential for desulfurization. These findings suggest that ultrasonically-assisted impregnation improves the surface acidity distribution of the catalysts. Additionally, a reduction in Brønsted acid sites may help minimize undesired side reactions, such as cracking, dealkylation, and isomerization, enhancing the selectivity of the catalysts in HDS reactions. 3.3 Catalytic activity The initial specific rates for the HDS reaction, expressed as molDBTgCat −1s −1, for the traditional and ultrasonic-assisted impregnation methods are presented in Fig. 9a. The catalysts synthesized using the traditional impregnation method exhibited lower initial reaction rates than those prepared with ultrasonic-assisted impregnation (Fig. 9a, the black bars on the right side). The catalyst with the lowest metal loading prepared by traditional impregnation (Imp-12) exhibited an initial reaction rate of 67x10−8 molDBTgCat −1s−1 (Fig. 9a). With increasing metal loading, the initial reaction rate improved, reaching 85x10 −8 and 97x10 −8 molDBTgCat −1s −1 values for the Imp-18 and Imp-24 catalysts, respectively. This represents a 26 % and 44 % increase in catalytic activity for the Imp-18 and Imp-24 catalysts, respectively, compared to the Imp-12 catalyst. However, the metal content of the Imp-18 and Imp-24 catalysts increased by 43 % and 83 %, respectively, compared to the Imp-12 catalyst. The increase in initial reaction rate relative to metal content tends to diminish as metal loading becomes higher. This indicates that the increase in the initial reaction rate becomes less proportional to metal content as metal loading rises, suggesting a decrease in catalyst efficiency relative to metal content at higher loadings. For comparison, the activity of a commercial KF-752 catalyst (Akzo Nobel) containing 17.5 wt% MoO3 and 4.9 wt% CoO, and atomic ratio of Co/Co + Mo) of 0.48) was included as a reference catalyst. The reference catalysts reached an initial reaction rate of 76x10 −8 molDBTgCat −1s −1, which is 14 % higher than the initial reaction rate of the Imp-12 catalyst. However, the reaction rate of the reference catalyst was 11.3 % and 25 % lower than those of the Imp-18 and Imp-24 catalysts, respectively. It is important to note that the reference catalyst has a total metal loading of 22.4 wt% (17.5 wt% MoO3 and 4.9 wt% CoO), which is 7.1 % and 37.5 % lower than that of the Imp-18 and Imp-24 catalyst, respectively. These results suggest that the increase in catalytic activity (initial reaction rate) is less proportional to metal loading at higher metal contents. This becomes evident when we divide the reaction rate increase by the metal content increase compared to the reference catalyst. For the Imp-18 and Imp-24 catalysts, the ratio of the reaction rate increase divide by the metal loading increase compared to the reference catalyst, this factor value resulting 1.59 (an 11.3 % increase in reaction rate for a 7.1 % increase in metal loading) and 0.67 (a 25 % increase in reaction rate for a 37.5 % increase in metal loading), respectively, compared to the initial rate of the reference catalyst. This indicates that for catalysts prepared by traditional impregnation, increased metal content did not significantly improve catalytic activity relative to the reference catalyst, which has a lower metallic load. The initial specific reaction rates for the ultrasonically-assisted catalysts display significantly higher catalytic activity compared to those prepared by the conventional impregnation method (Fig. 9a, the blue bars on the right side), indicating that ultrasonic assistance enhances catalytic properties. As expected, the ultrasonically assisted US-12 catalyst exhibited the lowest reaction rate within this series, with a value of 81x10 −8 molDBTgCat −1s −1. It is important to note that this catalyst showed a 20 % higher reaction rate compared to its counterpart Imp-12 catalyst prepared by conventional impregnation, which has the same metal content. In contrast to the traditional impregnation method, the initial reaction rate in the ultrasonically assisted catalyst series increased significantly with rising metal content, reaching values of 116x10 −8, 145x10 −8, 161x10 −8, and 173x10 −8 molDBTgCat −1s −1 for the US-18, US-24, US-30, and US-36 catalysts, respectively. It is noteworthy that although the US-12 catalyst contains up to 40 % less metal loading than the reference catalyst, it achieved an 8 % higher reaction rate than these catalysts. Interestingly, the US-18 and reference catalysts have very similar metal content, with only a 4 % difference between the two samples. The reaction rate for the US-18 catalyst was up to 50 % higher than the initial reaction rate of the reference catalyst. Even at higher metal loadings, the US-24, US-30, and US-36 catalysts exhibited initial reaction rates up to 1.9, 2.1, and 2.3 times higher than the reference catalyst. However, as observed in catalysts prepared by conventional impregnation, the increase in reaction rate relative to the metal loading ratio decreases significantly with an increment in the metal content. By examining the ratio of reaction rate increase to metal content increase relative to the reference catalyst, related to the reaction rate and metal content of the reference catalyst, we can quantify this more precisely. However, the reaction rate value achieved does not increase significantly towards high metal charge values. Notably, this effect is more pronounced in catalysts prepared by the traditional impregnation method. These observations suggest that, although sonochemical assistance enhances dispersion, surface interaction, and the promotion effect of Co with Mo for CoMoS phase formation, there appears to be a surface limit for dispersing the active phase. This limitation is evident in the decreasing reaction rate ratio to metal loading as the metal charge increases. To better understand the impact of metal loading on the initial reaction rate, we normalized the reaction rates by the metal content, expressed in moles, accounting for the amount of metal present in the mass of the catalyst used in each catalytic test. To better understand the real effect of metal content on catalytic activity, the reaction rates were normalized by the moles of metal present in the catalyst mass used during the reaction. Fig. 9b shows the initial specific rates normalized by the moles of metal present in the catalyst mass for both the traditional and ultrasonic-assisted impregnation methods. The reaction rate of the reference catalyst, normalized by the moles of contained metals, is also included in this figure. Catalysts prepared by the traditional impregnation method showed lower initial reaction rates normalized by mole of metals than those synthesized with ultrasonic-assisted impregnation, as shown by the black bars on the right side of Fig. 9b. Notably, the catalyst with the lowest metal content prepared by the traditional impregnation method (Imp-12) exhibited a normalized reaction rate up to 24 % higher than that of the reference catalyst. Additionally, the normalized initial reaction rate significantly decreased as metal loading increased. The Imp-18 catalyst exhibited a normalized reaction rate 3.5 % higher than the reference catalyst, whereas the Imp-24 catalyst (with the highest metal loading) showed a reaction rate up to 17 % lower than the reference catalyst. As previously discussed, the impact of increasing metal content on catalytic activity diminished as the metal loading increased. In contrast, the ultrasonically-assisted catalysts demonstrated a higher normalized reaction rate relative to metal content compared to the reference catalyst. With lower metal content, the US-12 and US-18 catalysts achieved normalized reaction rates 43 % and 41 % higher, respectively, than that of the reference catalyst. However, at intermediate metal content levels, such as with the US-24 catalyst, the normalized reaction rate decreased slightly, indicating a reduced effectiveness of increasing metal loading on the reaction rate. At higher metal contents (US-30 and US-36), a more pronounced decline in normalized reaction rate was observed. While the US-36 catalyst (with the highest metal loading) was still more active than the reference catalyst, it achieved only a 7 % higher normalized reaction rate. These findings suggest that although the ultrasonic-assisted method is significantly more effective than the traditional impregnation method, its efficiency diminishes considerably at higher metal loadings. Table 4 shows the selectivity and HYD/DDS ratios at 30 % DBT conversion for catalysts prepared using traditional and ultrasonic-assisted impregnation methods. The reaction products include biphenyl (BP), cyclohexylbenzene (CHB), dicyclohexyl (DCH), and tetrahydrodibenzothiophene (THDBT). The DBT hydrodesulfurization (HDS) reaction proceeds via two primary pathways: hydrogenation (HYD) and direct desulfurization (DDS), as depicted in Scheme 1. As shown in Scheme 1, BP is formed via the DDS pathway, while CHB, DCH, and THDBT are formed through the HYD pathway. In the HYD pathway of the HDS reaction, DBT is hydrogenated in the first step to form THDBT. Subsequently, sulfur is removed from this intermediate, forming CHB, which is further hydrogenated to produce DCH. In the DDS pathway, the C-S bond is cleaved via hydrogenolysis, leading to the formation of BP. Among the reaction products, BP was the main reaction product observed across all catalysts, including the reference catalyst. The preferential formation of BP (selectivity about 87.3–97.4 %) indicates that the DDS route of DBT transformation was the main with respect to HYD one. Regardless of the preparation method, BP production decreases with increasing metal content. A comparison of BP formation between the catalysts synthesized by traditional impregnation (Imp-12, Imp-18, and Imp-24) and their counterparts prepared using the ultrasonically assisted method (US-12, US-18, and US-24) reveals that BP production is lower for the ultrasonically assisted catalysts than for those prepared by traditional impregnation (Table 4). These findings suggest that the HDS of DBT via the DDS pathway is less favored in ultrasonically assisted catalysts compared to those prepared by the traditional impregnation method. The highest BP selectivity was achieved with the Imp-12 catalyst, which exhibited 97.4 % selectivity for BP formation, decreasing to 96.8 % and 95.2 % for the Imp-18 and Imp-24 catalysts, respectively. Among the catalysts synthesized using ultrasonic assistance, the highest BP formation was observed on the catalyst with the lowest metal content (US-12), achieving 95.4 % selectivity. This value was comparable to that of the Imp-24 catalyst, the highest metal content catalyst prepared by the traditional method. Notably, this 95.4 % of selectivity for BP formation was also very similar to that of the reference catalyst. The decrease in BP selectivity was more pronounced in the catalysts synthesized via ultrasonic assistance compared to those prepared by the traditional method (Table 4). BP formation progressively decreases with increasing metal content, decreasing for the US-18, US-24, US-30, and US-36 catalysts. Regardless of the catalyst preparation method, these results suggest that the hydrogenation pathway (Table 4) becomes increasingly favored as the metal content rises. To obtain information about the impact of the impregnation synthesis method on the preferential pathway during the HDS of DBT reaction, the HYD/DDS ratio was calculated based on the selectivity data presented in Table 4. Notably, the HYD/DDS ratio values were higher for the catalysts synthesized using ultrasonic assistance. This ratio increased with rising metal loading, further supporting the observations previously discussed. This trend could be attributed to the surface acidity of the catalysts, which increased with rising metal content (Table 3). While traditional impregnation predominantly favors the DDS pathway, ultrasonic-assisted impregnation promotes the HYD pathway, particularly at higher metal loadings. These findings highlight the significant influence of the synthesis method on reaction selectivity and catalytic activity in the HDS of DBT. To highlight the significance of ultrasonic-assisted impregnation method in catalyst synthesis, the results of this study have been compared with those of various supported molybdenum-based catalysts promoted by cobalt or nickel, trimetallic Mo-W catalysts promoted by nickel or cobalt, as well as some supported NiW catalysts, as compiled from the literature. Table 5 compiles relevant and representative results, detailing the catalyst composition, activation method, reaction conditions, initial reaction rate, and selectivity in the HDS of DBT. The Imp-24 and US-24 catalysts, each with a total metal oxide loading of 24 %, have a composition comparable to the catalysts described in Table 5. Therefore, the catalytic activity data for these catalysts have been included in the table for comparison. Among the catalysts listed in Table 5, the Imp-24 catalyst demonstrated a higher reaction rate than most of the other catalysts, highlighting the effectiveness of the Ti-HMS support in enhancing the performance of CoMo catalysts for the DBT HDS reaction. On the contrary, the US-24 catalyst exhibited a superior reaction rate compared to the catalysts in Table 5, with the exception of a trimetallic NiMoW catalyst also supported on Ti-HMS, notably, the reaction rates of both catalysts were comparable. These comparison demonstrate that ultrasonic-assisted synthesis positively influences catalyst performance. Even when compared to nickel-promoted catalysts, which are known to enhance the promotion of the active phase, the ultrasonic-assisted CoMo catalysts showed higher catalytic results. Additionally, the performance of these catalysts was on par with tungsten-based catalysts, which generally exhibit higher catalytic activity than molybdenum-based systems. Thus, the ultrasonic-assisted impregnation method proves to be highly effective in synthesizing catalysts with enhanced activity. In terms of selectivity, the HYD/DDS ratio for the catalysts synthesized in this study was generally lower than those of the other catalysts listed in Table 5. Only one catalyst in the table exhibited a similar selectivity ratio. A low HYD/DDS ratio can be advantageous, as it implies reduced hydrogen consumption during the reaction. However, it could also pose challenges for the hydrodesulfurization of refractory molecules. Therefore, further studies are necessary to explore this aspect and assess its impact on the overall efficiency of the hydroprocessing reaction. The characterization results confirm that ultrasonic-assisted synthesis significantly enhances the dispersion and interaction of cobalt and molybdenum species on the support surface, even at high metal loadings. The cavitation effect generated during sonication induces the implosive growth and collapse of microbubbles in the liquid medium and on the support surface. This phenomenon creates localized hotspots with extremely high temperatures and pressures, leading to pronounced physicochemical effects that promote uniform distribution of metal precursors, prevent agglomeration, and reduce the crystallization of metal oxides. These intense conditions activate hydroxyl (OH) groups on the support surface, facilitating stronger interactions between the supported species and the base material. Furthermore, ultrasonic energy can promote the formation of chemical bonds between catalytic species and the activated OH groups. This mechanism allows precise control over the nucleation and growth of particles, resulting in the formation of low-dimensional or low-crystallinity particles. Consequently, ultrasonic-assisted impregnation maximizes the utilization of the support surface and mitigates the formation of large agglomerates, even at high metal loadings. The higher dispersion achieved through ultrasonic assistance enhances the number of exposed active sites, as evidenced by the higher normalized reaction rates for ultrasonically assisted catalysts compared to those prepared by the traditional method. These advantages are reflected in improved catalytic performance, with a higher number of catalytically active sites contributing to superior reaction rates and selectivity. However, as metal loading increases, the limitations of surface dispersion become apparent, suggesting that further optimization of metal content and synthesis conditions is necessary to fully maximize the benefits of ultrasonic-assisted impregnation. 4 Conclusions This study demonstrates that the preparation method significantly influences the structural, electronic, and catalytic properties of CoMo catalysts for the HDS of DBT. The ultrasonic-assisted impregnation method demonstrated to be a highly effective method for enhancing the dispersion of Co and Mo species, improving the stronger Co-Mo species interactions, promoting the formation of well-dispersed CoMoS phase, enhancing complete sulfidation of the Co species, and improving surface acidity compared to traditional impregnation methods. Ultrasonically assisted catalysts demonstrated higher initial reaction rates compared to traditional impregnation catalysts. Despite similar metal loading, the US-18 catalyst showed a reaction rate 50 % higher than the reference catalyst, highlighting the advantages of ultrasonic assistance. While reaction rates increased with higher metal loadings, the proportional gain in catalytic activity, normalized by metal content, diminished at higher metal loadings for both preparation methods. However, this decrement was less pronounced in ultrasonically assisted catalysts, suggesting the higher effectiveness of ultrasonic assistance in achieving better dispersion of the active components. Biphenyl was identified as the primary reaction product across all catalysts, indicating that the direct desulfurization pathway was the main reaction pathway. Nevertheless, ultrasonic-assisted catalysts showed a greater contribution from the hydrogenation pathway during DBT HDS, particularly at higher metal loadings, as reflected by elevated HYD/DDS ratios. This behavior can be attributed to increased surface acidity and improved formation of brim sites in the MoS2 phase, both of which enhance hydrogen transfer reactions. Despite the superior catalytic performance of ultrasonic-assisted catalysts, the effectiveness of increasing metal content declined at very high loadings, likely due to limitations in active site dispersion and the shift from edge-dominated MoS2 structures to bulk phases. Overall, the ultrasonic-assisted impregnation method is promising for designing highly effective HDS catalysts that optimize metal loading. CRediT authorship contribution statement T.A. coredata.dc:description: Here, it reports the influence of ultrasonic assistance during the impregnation process using traditional precursor salts of cobalt nitrate, molybdenum heptamolybdate, and citric acid as a chelating agent. The variation in metal loading (CoO + MoO3) from 16.1 wt% (12.7 wt% MoO3, 3.4 wt% CoO) to 46.8 wt% (35.7 wt% MoO3, 10.1 wt% CoO) was evaluated in the HDS of DBT. Ultrasonically-assisted impregnation demonstrated improved metal dispersion, improved the Co-Mo interactions and complete sulfidation of cobalt species, and enhanced the formation of well-dispersed CoMoS phase, unlike traditional impregnation catalysts that even exhibited non-sulfided Co species. Catalysts prepared using ultrasonic assistance exhibited a higher initial reaction rate for the HDS of DBT than their traditionally impregnated counterparts. Although the direct desulfurization pathway was the primary reaction route, the ultrasonic-assisted catalysts exhibited higher selectivity toward the hydrogenation pathway (higher HYD/DDS ratios), especially at higher metal loadings. The increased surface acidity, which correlated with rising metal content, enhanced the hydrogenation pathway during the HDS of DBT. Despite the superior catalytic performance of ultrasonic-assisted catalysts, the effectiveness of increasing metal content decreases at higher metal loadings, likely due to limitations in active site dispersion on the surface.
